Award.AwardTitle: Perovskite and post-perovskite in the (Mg,Fe)GeO3 system
Award.AbstractNarration:
The geological activity at Earth's surface that can so profoundly affect humanity ultimately arises from on-going processes within the deep interior. These large-scale processes are in turn controlled by the properties of the constituent materials of the deep Earth. A mineral's crystal structure is its most fundamental characteristic, from which all other physical and chemical properties follow. Due to the incredibly high pressures (millions of atmospheres) and temperatures (thousands of degrees) of the deep Earth, our knowledge of the crystal structures of minerals residing near the base of Earth's mantle remains far from complete. This region of the Earth is primarily composed of silicate minerals that adopt structures known as perovskite and post perovskite. In this project, the PI will conduct laboratory experiments to probe the basic structural properties of magnesium iron germanates, a class of compounds that serve as close analogs for the silicate minerals of the deep Earth, but which can be studied at lower pressures and temperatures which are more easily attainable in the laboratory. Through this work, he and his team will provide fundamental knowledge of mineral crystal structures and properties that are needed to understand and interpret geophysical observations of the Earth's interior.

The Earth's deep lower mantle is key for understanding the overall structure, dynamics, and evolution of the planet. Seismic evidence indicates this region exhibits considerable chemical heterogeneity as exemplified by features such as large low shear velocity provinces, ultra-low velocity zones, and the complexity of the core-mantle boundary region. The PI will conduct high-pressure X-ray experiments on Fe-bearing compositions in the (Mg,Fe)GeO3 system, an analog for the silicates of the deep mantle. The advantage of this system is that the perovskite to post-perovskite transition occurs at much lower pressure for germanates, allowing the team to avoid or reduce the experimental complications that plague silicate studies at ultrahigh pressures. They will use the laser-heated diamond anvil cell to carry out a series of synchrotron-based studies of the crystal structure, equation of state, electronic configuration, and local environment of iron in germanates with the perovskite and post-perovskite structures. The results will lead to a better understanding of how iron content affects mineralogical behavior in these phases and will directly impact the fields of seismology, petrology, geodynamics, geochemistry, and mineralogy.

ProgramReference.Text: STUDIES OF THE EARTH'S DEEP INTERIOR

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our research program is aimed at understanding the large-scale structure and composition of the Earth and other planets.  We use laboratory experiments and computer calculations to determine the physical properties of geological materials under the extreme pressures and temperatures that exist deep inside the Earth.   In this specific project, we studied how the atomic structures of materials change under pressures as high as over one million atmospheres, comparable to the pressure at the Earth’s core-mantle boundary.  We specifically focused on oxide, fluoride, and germanate compounds, both crystals and glasses, that can serve as analogues for the silicate minerals of the deep Earth.  Analogues are compounds that behave similarly to silicates but undergo structural changes at lower pressures where they can be observed and characterized more readily in our experiments.  

Among the major highlights of this project are as follows:   1) we obtained new information on how the density and structure of germanium dioxide changes under compression;  2) we studied how the mechanical response of magnesium fluoride changes as it approaches a structural phase transition at high pressures; 3) we studied an unusual phase transition in lead fluoride.  All of these projects provide insight into corresponding behavior of silicon dioxide, the major oxide of the Earth’s vast lower mantle.  In addition, our study of lead fluoride also has relevance for oxides used as potential nuclear waste containment materials.  The other major accomplishment of our project was to better understand the structural changes that minerals undergo close to the Earth’s core-mantle boundary.  Here we used germanates ((Mg,Fe)GeO3) as analogues for the corresponding silicate ((Mg,Fe)SiO3) because they undergo a transition from the perovskite structure to the post-pervskite structure at lower pressures. Our main finding was to show that the presence of iron reduces the transition pressure.  This has implications for interpretation of seismic data from the deepest part of the mantle. It indicates that compositional as well as temperature changes are important for understanding the seismic discontinuity near the core.

Our work has provided advanced training for graduate and undergraduate students in the operation of sophisticated high-pressure devices and in optical spectroscopy and X-ray diffraction.  Students have also learned advanced data analysis and data processing techniques.  We have also trained students in presentation and writing skills, as well as more general professional development. Our work on this project has resulted in ten peer-review publications in which students were co-authors. The findings from this research have been incorporated into a review paper aimed at mineralogists and geophysicists. We have also incorporated our findings in classes at Princeton University and in public lectures.
